compressors for petroleum, chemical, and gas industry services
GM RC MEC 001: SAVER review of MSR by machine type
compressors condition monitoring and maintenance plan
The purpose of this document is to provide guidelines for the
selection guidelines and maintenance activities for any process
This guideline is applicable on all
plants according to CR RC MIT 402
Minimum Standard Requirements (MSR): rules, procedures and instructions which are essential for availability and/or HSE.
Recommendations (R): recommended practices, state of the art needed for a correct operation.
Valves are critical items in reciprocating compressors responsible
3 different types of valve are available on the market
Polymer disc type to be considered for application with low impact velocity since more sensitive to fatigue failure
Mixed results, so to be selected with great care
Recommended valve type since less sensitive to fatigue failure and more tolerant to liquid ingress.
Non metallic material of polymer or composite type offering high impact resistance shall be selected
Austenitic material may be selected for plate valve on low service temperature
The final selection is based on process gas, maximum temperature and pressure
Above temperature shall be taken as reference only and an op
shall be applied considering the differential pressure across the valve.
Gas velocity is a tradeoff between inefficiency (too high) and valve
In case of wide range of MW, for example Nitrogen start up, the valves shall be
design for the normal most frequent operating process case but carefully checked for suitability on intermittent start up condition for limited duration
shall be checked against the following limit for proper efficiency:
For medium gases MW<25: q below 5% (max 10%)
Spring material shall have excellent fatigue and corrosion resistance when exposed to H2S and chloride traces. Exotic materials are often required (
Special coating may be applied to improve service life.
A preventive replacement of all valves is recommended for
difference between 2 valves on the same effect)
indicates a valve leakage. The remaining valve life will depend on
leak rate and leak deterioration over time
An abnormal inter stage pressure increase indicates a leaking suction valve on upper stage.
gap between valve cover and cylinder. Lack of gap means improper valve seating
During removal, mark up valves, valve/seat gasket thickness plus distance between valves covers and cylinder, lanterns and
(for suction side) in order to match items per position
n the cylinder in the event of failure.
Caution when using hydraulic extracting tools
since valve distortion is very frequent.
A specific installation procedure shall be followed with great care
Check valve opening side before assembly in order to prevent mixing suction and discharge valves.

After installing gasket and suction valve in the well, always check the depth from valve to top of the bore on 3 different locations in order to confirm proper gasket centering and valve seating. For discharge valve, gasket shall be put on the valve and both shall be positioned simultaneously.
Specific tooling shall be used when necessary
Potential risk of gas path blockage
if not of fool proof mounting design
Always refer to OEM prescribed torque values
to be applied on bolt cover and pushdown bolts.
stem adjustment to ensure proper functionality.

for suction and discharge of each
Hold at least 2 per type complete
, hold one complete set of hydraulic actuators including hydraulic hoses and accumulators
and check seat soundness (no crack or dent)
Grind seat if damaged. Check new well depth versus valve thickness and lantern in order to maintain proper assembly
Valves shall be sent to valve OEM or to
expertise report with pictures in order to identify root cause of the failure, or possibility of run extension with similar configuration.
double check that valve thickness has not been reduced by more than 10% and record refurbishment thickness in log sheet.
are correctly tightened on their seat during valve cover
and clearance between cover and cylinder
for suction valves are still long enough to unload valve
and not too long to continuously unload valve
Valve location (suction/discharge, stage, compressor tag) shall be etched on valve body to facilitate identification during assembly.

are still compatible with new valves (unloading force is not the same for each valves technology)
